parameters: Thursday. The day after you didn’t show up for your appointment.
We just started spending time together.
You hardly know anything about me.
Your legal documents say something slightly different, but you haven’t told your coworkers that.
Others have responded poorly, so you’ve given up on trying to change names with people who already knew you.
It's easier to let it go than to deal with how they might react.
Your birth date is February 9, 1987. The year of the rabbit.
You work at a Korean restaurant four to six days a week.
The front of house staff are mostly women, and the kitchen staff are all men.
Despite covering shifts in both, you don't feel particularly welcome or like you fit in with either group.
But you like handwriting the signage. You enjoy decorating pastries. You're a great baker.
You attended art school for about a year and a half before withdrawing.
You never wanted to go, but you felt pressured into it as a first-generation college student.
Still, you're an art history buff. There's an expansive gallery of paintings in your mind, labels included.
After leaving school, you moved in with two roommates who are dating each other.
You feel like a third wheel and unwelcome in your own home.
You’re a middle child like me, second born.
Your mother doesn’t speak English well. You often had to translate for her as a child.
But you’re not confident in your abilities and would rather not have to do it.
You love animals. Especially rodents. You love insects, too.
You have a small but loyal following online for your artwork. Which is quite good, by the way.
And you are very strong in ways you may not always be aware of.
I badly want to know more.
And I can explain how I think we can get out of this.
...\|But I feel like I know what you're going to say.
As much as I wanted to, I can’t.
You’ve lied too many times about too many things.
I can’t believe you when you say you’ve thought this through enough to get away with it.
You stalked me obsessively for weeks.
You abducted and killed a stranger over someone you just started getting to actually know.
These aren't the actions of a level headed guy who's gonna cover up a murder plot successfully.
I know my actions seem imbalanced. Some of them are.
But even still, it would be in your best interest to cooperate with me.
You are heavily implicated in this.
The timing of your and his disappearances.
You restored cell service to your phone, so now it has been pinged at a tower nearby.
In other words, your phone was near the body just days after its expiration.
I don’t care. I won’t do things your way.
I’m not helping you out of this insane trap you laid.
You think you can just get rid of your problems even if that problem is a human being.
And here I am, becoming a problem to you.
So what are you gonna do?
Angel, what are YOU going to do? What is your plan?
Go back to your job? Go back to your apartment?
Will you go to the authorities, or will they come to you?
How do you think that’s going to go?
Your version of events will not withstand interrogation. They will charge you.
So I won’t say anything without a lawyer, I guess.
Listen to me. Public defender or not, they will pin you.
What sort of believable timeline could you present to them?
You didn’t even know what day it was this morning.
That's true. There's a lot I wasn't paying attention to.
Because I trusted you while you were deliberately blinding me.
Angel.\| Please.\| I need you\| to work with me.
We can still get out of this.
There is no need to bury yourself alive just to put me in the ground.
The very least you can do is stop when I say no.
If you can’t handle that, you aren’t any better than the guy you killed.
\|If, for any reason, we are interviewed and our stories aren't consistent, there is no way we will avoid prosecution.
If we can't agree on a narrative, I can't help you get out of this.
You shouldn’t have gotten me into this in the first place.
I'm leaving.\| I'm getting out of here.
I can see how the rest of my life will go.
I’ve known it as far back as I can remember.
I always felt safe standing in the corner.
You can't get in more trouble if you're already there.
You should go in the next ten seconds.
But I don’t think you're going to hurt me.
I just...\| even now, I don't freeze up when I'm with you.
You would have hurt me by now if you were going to.
I didn’t want this. I didn’t ask for this.
I said I regretted telling you what happened to me.
You acted against my will after I made it clear to you what I wanted.
Does any of this sound familiar?
I think he would do it again in the future. \|Hurt people.
He’d done it in the past. I overheard him telling one of the servers.
He kept trying to downplay it, like, “Oh, she had a good lawyer...”
You didn’t know that, though, did you? Before?
So you were just getting revenge.
You didn’t want to leave your job. You made a good point, that you shouldn’t have to.
I decided to prevent him from causing you future harm. \|Permanently.
Okay, but you’ve screwed me over for life. Right?
There’s no way I’m not implicated in this now.
...\|I agree it would have been far better if you had never seen this.
I had planned to get the supplies to conceal his body after work.
It was shortsighted of me. When you didn’t show up on Wednesday, I worried.
I wanted to act sooner than later. I had no idea you’d come on Friday.
\|So you were gonna do it even if I never came back?
Your phone dying on the ride over here was a blessing.
I installed the cell jammer before you plugged your phone in to charge.
It meant no cell towers could ping your phone for days.
So that’s what that thing was in the closet.
Dozens of missed calls would have been far worse.
But, like, why didn’t my work call or text me?
It could mean the police advised your workplace not to contact you.
...\|Or it could mean you work in food service where turnover rates are high and people cold quit all the time.
Why haven’t my roommates asked me where I am?
It could mean detectives are combing your room as we speak.
...\|Or it could mean your roommates are relieved to have the place to themselves.
So you don’t know. You don't know anything.
I knew you paid your rent for the month shortly before coming with me, so they were less likely to mind your absence.
Missing person investigations like this are very time sensitive.
They aren't particularly high priority for adult men, either.
We have already made it three days since I pronounced time of death. That’s promising.
I just couldn’t leave to get the materials to hide the body with you here. You would have had questions.
Concrete mix, gravel, tarp, a wheelbarrow, a couple tools.
I’ll bury the body and the evidence and lay a concrete floor over it down here.
Like I said, this basement isn’t part of the floor plan.
It is much safer to keep everything down here than attempt to move it and spread proof around.
I found it awfully easily, though.
Only because you flipped that switch in the interstitial space behind the bedroom wall.
That unlatched the false back of the closet. It’s usually unnoticeable.
Once I seal the entrance up, it will be like none of this ever existed.
But our stories need to be completely consistent.
We can still get away with this if you are willing to work with me.
Has it really been three days?
This room is like a sealed container, and the weather's been cold. It’s not conducive to decomposition.
Is his car still at the bakery parking lot?
Wouldn't that, y'know, make it obvious something's wrong?
His car is 100 miles east and 30 feet deep in water with the plates removed and the VIN scratched off.
I can go over minute by minute with you what I did. Write it down for your review, even, and destroy it after.
\.\.I probably wouldn't be able to read it.
But I do think it's better if I don't give you every detail. It's harder to slip up when questioned if you don't know in the first place.
There’s no way I can navigate out of this by myself.
I don’t want to go to jail. I don’t want you to go to jail.
You really think you can do it?
If we do pull this off, and I do...\| stay in your life...\| you have to move.
I’m not sleeping in a house with a literal skeleton in the closet.
I don’t know how you’ve been able to.
Selling property doesn’t happen overnight, but I will make it happen.
Right. One thing at a time.
Tell me right now if you are hiding anything else.
I cannot take even one more curveball. No matter how small. I’m serious.
You already found the\.\. cabinet of your things. That was all I had.
Everything else that I hid, I hid to not implicate you.
I am completely out of things I wanted or needed to conceal from you.
...\|How come you're so calm about all this when you were so sweaty about the shrine?
If you had rejected me when you found that, I would have regretted it.
But I don't regret what I did down here. \|I don't.
I’m kind of at your mercy here.
Yeah. Tell me what to do.
this is just backup i think
